Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Factor graph computing for data-driven decision-making
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to democratize the power of machine learning and predictive analytics to help non-engineering business personnel realize the full value of their data. Enabling this will drive better organizational decision making at all levels and the creation of additional business value for commercial and governmental organizations of all kinds, and of all sizes. Data-driven decisions using big data analytics holds massive promise, but has largely remained unfulfilled primarily because, in its current form, it is unaffordable to all but the most technologically advanced organizations. Data-driven businesses have 5-6% higher productivity and can potentially add $3 Trillion in value globally, per year. A wide range of sectors, such as manufacturing, retail, finance, healthcare, security, and governmental services will see significant commercial impact including higher productivity, better utilization of resources, and the acceleration of the deployment of new products, services, and technologies. By enabling commercial and governmental entities to more effectively utilize their data and resources, businesses and government agencies will increase their productivity, more effectively utilize their personnel, improve their competitiveness, and eliminate waste resources while increasing the flow of products and services that benefit society at large.

This I-Corps project is based on ground breaking technology meant to realize a scalable, flexible and easy-to-use data-processing infrastructure. At the highest level, building such a platform requires: (a) coming up with the right abstraction or language that accommodates all sorts of computation at scale; (b) implementing the architecture to realize such computation at scale; (c) the ability to go from "sandboxing" or "prototyping" to a production environment instantly; and (d) the ability to work in heterogenous data environments instantly. We have put forth a novel computational language, called factor graph computing. Such a computation framework is "Turing complete". Factor graph computing allows for performing data transformation, predictive modeling, and optimization at scale to enable data-driven decisions. Such a platform eliminates the need for data engineering, provides flexibility to build predictive models instantly, allows for seamless evolution by bringing in new datasets in the mix, and requires minimal support to maintain the infrastructure and allow for generating prescriptive decisions at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Research at MIT has developed ground breaking technology to realize a scalable, flexible and easy-to-use data-processing infrastructure. At the highest level, building such a platform requires: (a) coming up with the right abstraction or language that accommodates all sorts of computation at scale; (b) implementing the architecture to realize such computation at scale; (c) the ability to go from ?sandboxing? or ?prototyping? to a production environment instantly; and (d) the ability to work in heterogenous data environments instantly. Building on the research of more than a decade at MIT, our enduring comparative advantage, on the topic of graphical models, we have put forth a novel computational language, called factor graph computing. Such a computation framework is ?Turing complete?. Factor graph computing allows for performing data transformation, predictive modeling, and optimization at scale to enable data-driven decisions. Such a platform eliminates the need for data engineering, provides flexibility to build predictive models instantly, allows for seamless evolution by bringing in new datasets in the mix, and requires minimal support to maintain the infrastructure and allow for generating prescriptive decisions at scale.

Key Outcomes or Other Achievements

Discovery of Customer Segments - The team found a clear value proposition for its technology, with application to direct purchasing managers at small to medium manufacturers. In particular, based on the team?s 100+ customer discovery interviews, the manual and time-consuming nature of the negotiation planning process results in purchasing managers failing to realize significant cost savings during vendor negotiations due to a lack of data-driven insights for informed negotiation decisions.

Over the course of the program, the team learned that purchasing managers are evaluated on their ability to save costs and to hit certain cost savings goals. They work with suppliers on a year-round basis to source required items, and negotiate prices and terms to achieve these goals. Products, prices, and vendor data are routinely analyzed to inform these negotiation strategies for item sourcing. However, the process of using data to inform negotiation strategies is extremely manual and time consuming. It involves manually bringing in constantly fluctuating commodities prices, analyzing thousands of vendor risk profiles, product costs, timelines, and manually working through different combinations of ?what-if? scenarios in Excel. If the price of a single commodity, such as paper, changes by 50 cents, a purchasing team must manually update these thousands of data points and must re-run all scenarios. Every single sourcing negotiation can take upwards of 2 weeks to prepare for, and 20-30% of time is spent just analyzing and handling the data.

Other significant outcomes

●  Continued relationships with customers from interviews to help with customer validation stage
●  NSF SBIR Phase I grant award
●  Both EL and TL are still working together on this via SBIR and other funding sources

●  Continued application of I-Corps methodology to discover new use cases for our technology in areas such as healthcare and retail

●  Initial customer traction

●  Created Jobs: Hired team of engineers to build the product based on this technology

 

Broader Impacts: Data-driven decisions hold promise to produce additional 3 Trillion USD globally per year as per McKinsey Global Institute. The businesses that utilize data driven decisions are found to have 5-6% higher productivity as per MIT Sloan School of Management. The individual income can be increased globally by close to a Trillion dollars because of data as per an estimate of Omidyar Network.

A survey of the Global 2000 indicated that over 60% are putting Digital Transformation at the heart of their corporate strategy, with $2 Trillion being spent worldwide. They believe 30% of new applications will come from low code / no code environments, and 45% of companies surveyed indicated business intelligence and analytics as their top IT priority for 2018 (Red Hat).

The factor graph computing infrastructure, invented at MIT, provides such a low/no-code environment for running the most complex of decision-making algorithms to democratize the power of machine learning and predictive analytics to help non-engineering business personnel realize the full value of their data.


Last Modified: 05/31/2020
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
